conversations.content: The Officers Academy: a training ground for those who would one day serve the Alberian royal family. I longed for knighthood, knowing it would deliver me from the bottom rung of society I was born into. Upon enrolling, my acumen was quickly noted.

I never doubted for a second that I was on the path toward accomplishing my dream. I swore I would use my platform to create a world where every human being would be treated equally, regardless of their birth or social standing.

But all that awaited me was the bitter sting of reality. Leif and Cecile, both of noble birth, received stations within the Royal Guard. Meanwhile, I—a commoner—was doomed to become part of the worthless Capital Guard.
Three years later...
Harle, I hereby appoint you chief of the Capital Guard.
...I humbly and gratefully accept.
(Pitiful that this is the highest station a commoner could ever hope to reach.)
(There's no future for a country that values social standing above all. I must enact my plan.)
Congratulations on your promotion.
But I must say, I question my father's logic in appointing you as such.
A knight of your skill is far more suited to a position within the Royal Guard.
Why, Prince Phares. I am honored that you would think so. Truly, you give me too much credit.
I only speak the truth. In fact, it is for that reason I have come to you today.
Harle, I would like you to serve as my personal guard.
Given your other recent appointment, it may be quite the endeavor to take both positions at once—this I recognize.
I am most humbled by your words. If I may ask, what moved you to approach a man of my lowly caliber?
Because I believe only you can live up to my expectations. Do you accept my offer?
(It sounds too good to be true, but this is undoubtedly a tremendous opportunity.)
(I may not know what His Highness's true intentions are, but I will use him in kind.)
I would be a fool to turn down such a privilege. I am yours to command, sir.
After you, Your Highness.
Thank you for your hard work, and for seeing me home to my research lab. I feel more at  ease here than in the castle.
I would never have guessed that this place housed a laboratory.
Leif said the same thing.
Did he, now?
Indeed. In the past, I would occasionally ask him to go on errands for me. The man is dependable to a fault, really.
His family has served mine for generations, so we go back quite a ways.
Incidentally, I'd been meaning to ask... What were you doing before you joined the Officers Academy?
I was a meager servant for a nobleman.
Interesting. What made you aspire to knighthood?
My master at the time was the picture of magnanimity. He would make any number of arrangements to see a young man's future brighten.
You certainly lucked out, didn't you? Still, I must caution you against lying.
I beg your pardon? I do not recall spinning any falsehoods, Your Highness.
A few years ago, a nobleman was exiled after committing an unspeakable crime.
It sounds like a most terrible incident. And yet I fail to see what it has to do with present conversation, sir.
Funny you should ask. It happened around the same time you attained knighthood.
Surely a man of your intellect is aware that if servant were to, say, report his master's crimes to the crown, he would be duly rewarded.
And you believe I would do such a thing? You jest. Why, that would be uncivilized.
Ah. My apologies, then. However, an interesting story does spring to mind. Perhaps you've heard it.
Not long ago, a messenger arrived from Grams for a...secret rendezvous, we'll say.
And who was their contact? My sources described him as a knight clad in black. Why, that sounds just like you.
Heavens! What a misunderstanding this is. I did indeed meet with the messenger in question, but I was simply showing him around the capital. I AM chief of its guard.
Oh, is that all? Here I was certain you were sharing intelligence.
You wish to create a world where all human beings stand shoulder to shoulder as equals.
But such a thing is impossible in a kingdom with a class system. Therefore...
It would only be natural for you to devise a plan to destroy this kingdom and build one that suits your ideals upon its ashes.
You certainly live up to your reputation as an esteemed researcher, my liege. That is quite the theory you have crafted.
But I'm afraid a theory is all it is. My loyalty lies with the Kingdom of Alberia.
I see. Forgive me—I've always been prone to overthinking. Terrible habit.
Now, I must concentrate on my research, so please stand by outside for me.
Your wish is my command.
(How much does that man know?! And if he already pieced all that together, then why did he take me on as his personal guard?)
Heh. I think I shall do a little bit of research of my own, Prince Phares.
Now, if I were looking for information of any importance, it would be right...here.
There's got to be something useful... Hm... What do we have here—an old research paper?
The Progenitor... Demons... So he's not your everyday research scientist after all. And there's another book shoved into the back of the shelf...
A child's handwriting, no doubt. It seems to be a journal he kept as a child.
＂Day 13, Month of the Lovely Dragon: It appears this will be my final entry.＂
＂My disease continues to plague me. I suffer from a kind of sensory paralysis. I lack all strength. My pulse slows. My hands are ice. My mind is in disarray.＂
Odd. There's no record of the Prince's condition progressing this far in the royal archives.
＂Day 14, Month of the Lovely Dragon: I am alive! New strength courses through my body.＂
He recovered in a single day? Wait... No. If that previous paper is to be believed...
The Progenitor... Reincarnation... Vessels... An undying body... It can't be!
Now this won't do. You should know better than to barge into someone's private study.
I did not peg you as the scholarly type.
Prince Phares... No, perhaps I should call you by the name of the entity living within you.
I haven't the faintest idea what you mean. More importantly, I have somebody I'd like you to meet. Say hello.
A pleasure to meet you at last. From now on, I will be known as Harle.
Who the hell are you?!
Did you not hear? His name is Harle. Oh, but there is no need to fret.
Ever since you became my guard, he has been lurking in the shadows, peering at your memories.
I am certain he will be the perfect replacement for you.
Now I understand. THIS was why you wanted me at arm's length.
Those twisted little ideas festering inside you suited him quite well.
We couldn't have asked for a better person's life to usurp.
Well, what an honor that is.
Now. You're a smart man. I'm sure you know what must happen next.
There cannot be two Harles in this world.
One moment. If you're just going to kill him, why don't you let me play with him instead?
I've seen into this man's memories. He is QUITE the idealist.
Wouldn't it be exciting to see him crushed by the weight of his own foolish notions?
I've no particular interest in such a thing, but by all means, do as you see fit.
What do you think you're—
No more struggling. It's time we said goodbye.
A tear in space?! Nngh... I'm... I'm getting sucked in! AGH!
Farewell, old Harle. Have yourself a fun little sojourn in another world.
Ngh... Where is this? Am I...still alive?
What a desolate place... Where in the world did they dump me?
That volcano... Am I in Valkaheim?
Heed me, my subjects! The Kingdom of Alberia has at last been unified under the eldest of its royals, Leonidas!
Hail our unity! Hail King Leonidas!
(Prince Leonidas did what? Nonsense. I've never heard anything about this.)
Listen well as we elucidate the new status quo. Prime Minister, if you would?
(＂Prime Minister＂? Wait... Is that—?!)
Listen well as we elucidate the new status quo. Prime Minister, if you would?
(＂Prime Minister＂? Wait... Is that—?!)
Thank you, my liege.
(Is that...me?)
(Events unlike any I've known have transpired here, and a man with my face saunters about... I understand now. This must be another world.)
(After being here for a few days, I've ascertained three things.)
(One: there was a war between humans and dragons, and the humans won.)
(Two: Alberia is currently ruled by Prince Leonidas and this world's version of me.)
(And three: everyone in this world is treated equally without regard to class.)
It's a cruel irony that my ideals would come true in a world devastated by war.
But unfortunately for my impostor, this is not enough to break me. I WILL return to my world and make him pay for this.
Yet I suppose that's easier said than done. Without any dragons in this world, is there anyone left to ferry me back to mine?
Oh, there you are, Prime Minister!
Hm?
His Highness sends word that your meeting has been rescheduled.
(This could be my chance... Those in power have access to limitless intel. Infiltrating the castle would be a major step forward.)
(And if I go there, I should be able to meet HIM as well...)
Yes, of course. We mustn't delay, then.
That's the last of today's plans sorted.
It's odd, though. Some of the soldiers were saying the strangest things.
How I'd abruptly disappear from one room only to appear in another just as suddenly. How is that even possible?
Oh, it's possible, given that I was the subject of their confusion.
It is good to meet you, Harle of this world.
Curious. No mirror stands before me, and yet... Who or what are you?
I am no reflection. I am you— Harle from another world.
Fascinating. I've heard of this concept— how there exists countless other worlds, and within them, other possibilities.
And you're saying you have come from one such divergence?
Brilliant deduction. I would have expected nothing less of myself.
Do you really expect me to believe such a ridiculous notion?
That is up to you. If you don't,  feel free to call your soldiers here.
(He's thinking about it. I knew he wouldn't make a snap judgment like that.)
(It seems that even in other worlds, a person's true nature never changes.)
(If he really IS me, he's likely weighing the benefits of using me now. He wouldn't even think of killing me right away.)
Very well. I'll hear you out. Why have you come here?
I'll get straight to the point. Will you work together with me?
In what fashion?
I would serve as your shadow.
Naturally, you would benefit from the arrangement as well.
After all... It would help you in your quest to create a world without social classes.
Oh? And why might you think that is my ultimate goal?
The fact that you serve King Leonidas is proof.
After a few days of studying Valkaheim, I have learned that even here, His Masjesty prefers a meritocracy.
To enact reform, it would be useful to have someone at the top with a similar ideology to your own. And so, you chose His Majesty.
However, even if the upper echelons laud meritocracy, there are still those who would be against the change you seek.
Would it not be convenient to have a confidant who will eliminate any who would impede you?
You're quite straightforward in offering to get your hands dirty in my stead.
That was my intent.
I see. But permit me to make one little correction to your assessment.
I do not pursue reform. No, I seek something far greater.
Namely a revolution.
What do you mean?
Thanks to King Leonidas, we have freed ourselves from the yoke of the dragons and built a land of meritocracy... But it's still not enough.
There remains a king. Thus, the confines of class still bind us.
I want to create a land of democracy.
And in order to do that, the very notion of royalty must be made a thing of the past. Do you understand what I'm trying to say?
It's to be a bloodbath, then.
Indeed. So if you desire to be my shadow, it means you'll also be the umbrella sheltering me when that blood spills.
Is whatever you wish to gain out of our deal worth that risk?
Being able to work hand in hand with you is a boon in and of itself.
I was cast into this world in a freak accident. Having a trustworthy confidant of my own would put my heart at ease.
Black though it may be... Very well. If you've already taken that into consideration, then I think you've made yourself worthy of my trust.
I accept ＂my＂ offer.
I am quite pleased to have earned ＂my＂ own trust.
Let us keep this arrangement a secret. No one else can know there are two of us.
Agreed. We will need every advantage to prepare for a revolution, after all.
(That's one step closer.)
(Now that I've secured an ＂ally＂ of sorts, all that's left is find a way back home...)
(That fool will pay for what he did to me. The stage for my revenge is set.)
Several years after Harle was sent to another world...
(I've learned quite a bit about my place of exile, but I've yet to find a way home.)
That man doesn't understand a THING!
My, my. What's gotten you so worked up?
Oh. You. *sigh* I'm simply fed up with King Leonidas's naïveté.
That's certainly not a word I'd use to describe His Majesty. ＂Strict＂ or ＂unrelenting,＂ maybe. What happened?
You know about how this world is facing desertification, yes?
I do. It would seem the grave consequence of eradicating those dragons is happening quicker than expected. We can't keep up.
I hear that even the old capital, Sol Alberia, has been swallowed by sand.
('Twas disorder they sowed, and now they reap.)
We're migrating those who lost their homes to safer places—like Valkaheim.
The problem is, we're running low on resources. We simply can't afford to waste them on the weak.
Thus, I suggested we should instead trim the fat. Get rid of those devoid of use. I've even drafted a plan for it here.
＂On Saving the Nation.＂ Hm... I can certainly see the efficiency in it all. What did King Leonidas have to say?
That we will not change course. And he wouldn't hear anything to the contrary.
A country cannot grow if we prune the buds of talent before they even develop.
The weak will die out whether we have a hand in their culling or not. Yet we must also wait for those who would one day become stronger.
The grace he would grant is nothing but a waste of precious time and resources.
A rather hasty judgment, don't you think?
Not at all. I've had plenty of time to mull it over. No matter how long we wait, we'll never find a leader more exceptional or talented than myself.
The time is ripe. We need to enact our plan to assassinate the king. I will rule in his stead.
You really wish to take on such a bothersome role?
If a ruler outlives his use, I have no choice but to seize his power for myself. The hour for revolution is nigh.
Heh... I can only imagine the look on his face when his authority is stripped away by a man who crawled up the ranks from base servitude!
Someone is here. I'll hide.
Hm. I could have sworn I heard someone else in here.
Your ears play tricks, fair madam. Now, your report, if you will.
With that, I must take my leave. Should you find anything amiss, do contact me.
I will. Your help is always appreciated.
Who was that?
That was Cassandra, the court sorceress. Was she not in your world?
I know her name, but I have never met her personally.
She was retired, but the former king's will decreed that she support King Leonidas.
I have asked her to do some research into other worlds. In particular, to see if it's possible to voluntarily open a gate into one of them.
...! Why are you asking that?
To trim the fat, remember? It'd be too much trouble to kill the weak, so I thought we could instead round them up and dump them into another world.
...I suppose we could.
That was quicker than I expected. Did you forget something?
It is a pleasure to meet you, Lady Cassandra. I have come seeking your wisdom. My name is Harle.
Is this some sort of jest? We JUST saw each other earlier today.
You did in fact meet with the Harle of this world. However, this would be your first time meeting me.
Explain yourself.
I see... So essentially, you're a foreign body that was shoved into this world by someone else.
Do you believe me?
For the time being. Now, what is it you want from me?
It's quite a simple request. I would like to work together to find a way back to the world whence I came.
Sorry, but no. Your situation is pitiable, but I've far too much on my plate as well.
I'd not dream of assuming otherwise. Indeed, no matter how much you do believe me, I've spun quite the yarn.
You wouldn't have time to focus on something so far-fetched. I certainly understand that. However...
What if I were to offer myself as a test subject?
What do you mean?
From what I can tell, you have an impressive collection of books on communing with the dead and bringing them back to life in here.
I'd wager you have your own reasons for agreeing to perform the other Harle's research.
And what better research subject than a man from another world? Tempting, no?
...You certainly are observant.
From then on, I helped Cassandra with her research, and in turn was able to investigate means of getting back home.
But one day, we suddenly lost contact. I didn't hear from her for several months.
What happened? The way I lost touch with you so suddenly, I'd thought you'd died.
My apologies. There was something I needed to test.
And? Did it bear fruit?
You understand what a chain of causality is, right?
It's the force that tethers a person to their world, no? So that even if you manage to travel through time, you'll quickly be pulled back to where you came from.
Correct. And a different time is the same thing as a different world. Normally, it would be impossible for someone to exist in another world for as long as you have.
Not that one would expect otherwise. For two of the same person cannot exist in the same world.
Worlds themselves are quite delicate, you see. They'll try to correct paradoxes and remove any sorts of foreign bodies.
And yet, I have been able to remain here for some time now.
That's right. According to my research, the only way that's possible is to either use the Dawnshard or to be severed from the chain of causality.
And yet, as I told you,  I have nothing of the sort in my possession.
Which leaves us with only one option.
Though even if that's the case, there should be a limit to how long you're able to stay in another world.
I wasn't getting anywhere without looking into that. So I performed a little experiment.
And that was?
To see if your chain of causality really had been severed.
Those affected by this phenomenon cannot remain in people's memories.
After a few months without contact, no trace of you would remain in the mind of another.
Thus did I purposely keep some distance from you. However, no matter how long I was away, I could still remember you.
So does that mean...my chain of causality WASN'T severed?
It's the only theory that holds water. It also helps me understand why you've been able to stay here for so long.
It means that your chain of causality is yet bound to your original world.
Is that even possible?
I wish I knew for certain. Do you know of anyone who could wield influence over such a thing?
...Yes, now that I think about it.
Well, then I hate to say it, but you're going to have to do something about them, or else you're stuck here forever.
...No. There is another way.
There is?
If I can't interfere with my chain of causality myself, then perhaps I should simply have myself removed from this world.
You can't mean—!
Unfortunately, this is where our collaborative efforts come to an end.
Hold it! While that method may indeed force the world to right itself...
If something goes awry, not only will you be unable to return whence you came, but you might simply cease to exist! Are you sure about this?
...Our partnership has been fruitful indeed, my lady. I pray that your wish shall one day come true.
Now, let us begin. The climax of this story is upon us.
My first master was a tremendous fool. His greed, temper, and lechery knew no bounds. His intellect and quality of character were nonexistent.
Why is it that these dolts manage to rise through the ranks while the lowborn flounder in the dirt? It always vexed me. That's why I swore I'd pull myself up to the top using any means necessary.
I had to act, or nothing would change. I would use anyone or anything I needed to achieve my goals.
That's how I've lived my life, ever since I was a child...
You've devised a strategy to kill King Leonidas?
I have indeed. You and I are the only ones who know of our...twofold nature. We are going to use that.
First, we will switch places. You will stand by at the northern border in order to create an alibi for yourself.
Meanwhile, I will kill the King and make myself scarce. After that, all you have to do is choose a culprit and become everyone's hero.
With such a glorious exploit under your belt, carrying out your revolution will be child's play. ...Well?
Hm. Devious. I like it.
(It should be about time now...)
(My scheme to kill the king was a bald- faced lie. Now that he's waiting at the checkpoint as planned, I'll strike him down from behind!)
It went right through him?!
Surround him!
What?!
Heh. Why so surprised?
I don't recall advising you to stage an ambush as part of our plan.
Which plan was that, now? The one to kill King Leonidas?
Or the one to kill me?
I did a bit of research into the concept of other worlds myself.
If I were to die, then the existence of any ＂Harle＂ would become impossible within this world. Now, what would happen after that?
The realm would try to right itself, thereby removing you from it.
And you hoped to use that phenomenon as a means of returning to your world. Does that about sum it up?
Brilliant work. I thought for certain my lie would be sufficient, but I suppose there's no fooling myself.
You are me, after all. It's only natural that I'd know exactly what you're thinking.
What a shame. I really thought we had a beautiful partnership.
Kill him.
Right away!
Hahaha... HAHAHAHAHA!
Huh?!
Faced with death, you lose your wits, I see.
I am of sound mind, I assure you. I simply find your soldiers' loyalty to you most amusing. They ought to choose their leader more carefully..
What?
Oh, you there. I'm about to die, so I'd like to give this to you.
Some kind of document? ...Wh-what IS this?!
＂On Saving the Nation...＂ You want to eliminate anyone too weak to be of use?
Why do you have that?!
Oh, do be sure you read until the end. Whose signature is on there?
Harle... It can't be. You didn't write this, did you, Prime Minister?
He did. It would seem that the great and talented Harle of this world drafted this plan in hopes of saving Valkaheim.
He said there was no use wasting time and resources on the weak—no point in giving them even a passing chance.
Hmph! What do I care if you show this to my soldiers here?
If you're interested in the specifics of my plan, I will tell you all about it later. Right now, you have a would-be assassin to kill!
What are you waiting for?! KILL HIM!
We aren't going to listen to someone who would stoop to such barbarism.
Excuse me?! ＂BARBARISM＂? In a world brought to ruin, we have no choice BUT to elevate the exceptional!
Ever hear of the food chain? You're all benefiting from it! So why does this bother you?!
But that doesn't mean that the strong should rob the weak of the right to live!
Still your wicked tongue! This is desertion—treason!
And so the pot admonishes the kettle. I understand now why you were at odds with King Leonidas. Farewell.
Well, well. How the tables have turned.
You little... Why did you have that with you?!
You are me, after all. It's only natural that I'd know exactly what you're thinking.
I thought you might try to lure me into a trap, so I brought it as a bit of insurance.
YOU...!
What lukewarm swordplay. Have you forgotten how to fight now that you're prime minister?
Ggh!
Come, now. You're WIDE open!
(We're one and the same. How can the gulf between us be so wide?!)
(But even HE can't defend himself against a sneak attack!)
Who's wide open NOW? HAH!
What did I just say? I know EXACTLY what you're thinking.
I know that I would try to go after my opponent's weak point. If you don't try to fight fairly, I'll know exactly what you're doing.
Like SO!
GRAAAGH! Nngh... Wait. Let's make a deal...
*cough* *wheeze* When I become ruler, I'll share the position with you...
Not as my shadow, but as an equal. Our ideals are the same, aren't they? I'm offering you the deal of a lifetime...
Don't make me laugh. We are nowhere near the same.
You became drunk with power. You forgot what your ideals were. It makes me sick to think you believe we're cut from the same cloth.
What...?
My dream is to create a world where everyone will be treated as equals, regardless of the circumstances of their birth or their social standing.
Exactly! That's why I—
You've forgotten that. Otherwise, you would never have thought to ＂trim the fat.＂ It's the exact kind of classism we swore to eliminate.
There are fools and weaklings in this world, to be sure. Though they may seem worthless at a glance, you can use them.
Have you forgotten that our path to knighthood was paved on the back of our nitwit master?
The real reason you're willing to cast away the weak without a thought is because you're afraid that someone exceptional will rise up in the ranks.
You were afraid they might usurp your position...the same way you did.
That's not—
How funny it is that you fear your own methodology. And yet, you rested on your laurels, not even bothering to practice your swordsmanship... How very sad for you.
You're no different from the weaklings you sought to eliminate.
No, please! Don't do it!
And like I said, even the weak have their uses—yours will be as my stepping stone.
NOOOOO!
Is this who I would become in the event that my ideals are realized?
Oh... It's already started. Now, the question is whether I will disappear or return to my world. We're about to see.
I'll use anyone or anything I need to achieve my goals.
Even my own life! Even the very laws of nature! I will use it all!
Wait. This is...
Well, well! It seems I finally made it back to this side.
Now all that's left is to enjoy my revenge on him for banishing me to another world.
He'll surely realize I've returned by now, given all of his meddling with the chain of causality.
This feeling... It would seem I've lost my grip on causality.
Well, well. Impressive for him to resist succumbing to despair after coming face- to-face with the untimely end of his own ideals.
But his timing couldn't be more perfect. Now he can attend our grand revel. What a raucous affair it promises to be.
I never thought I'd say the same things they said to me...
The battle is won.
No... I can still fight!
Of course you can. We can't be knocking someone out of commission during a mere mock battle.
So, what? You're saying you held back, then? Goodness me, things must be so SIMPLE for a model student.
You're the one who MADE it simple for me, Harle.
Excuse me?
You need to learn how to fight fairly rather than just using sneak attacks.
If you keep this up, it will come back to bite you in the future. Quit now while you still can.
Grrr... The NERVE of him...
That's just Leif's way of giving you advice.
If you're always fixated on ambushing your foe, you're restricting yourself to only one strategy.
And if your opponent has done their homework, they'll be able to read you like a book every single time.
What Leif is trying to impress is that you should learn how to attack from the front and vary your tactics.
Then why doesn't he just say that instead of talking around it in riddles?
Would you have listened to him if he did?
If you can master a variety of fighting styles, you'll hold your own against us and then some.
After all, toying with your opponents is your specialty.
Heh... I suppose you're right. I'll strive to be that kind of knight, then.
It'll help me claw my way up as well.
The reason I managed to defeat my other self was because I was a knight instead of a prime minister.
What irony that I, who cast aside the knightly code and betrayed my country, would one day be saved by the sword I swore on.
My rise to that position was only meant to be a method of making my ideals a reality.
And yet the one who accomplished just that wound up becoming quite the worthless wretch.
(To say nothing of his world's inevitable demise...)
Wouldn't it be exciting to see him crushed by the weight of his own foolish notions?
He wanted me to believe that my ideals are worthless, did he?
Hahaha... HAHAHAHA!
If I am to be corrupted by the realization of those ambitions, then all I have to do is create a future where that does not come to pass!
I will succeed with FAR greater panache than he ever did.
I must thank him for oh-so-kindly showing me what the face of failure looks like.
The wings of the Black Raven will never be clipped. Let my tale of revenge...begin!
